column4: bound up "Japanese counts higher numbers in units of ten thousand
column6: which advances according to units of one thousand. (Thus
column9: 000 would be read ""four ten-thousands"" by a Japanese.) Given that the comma is used in larger numbers to bind up a numerical unit of one thousand
column10: the elements for one and bound up naturally come to form ten thousand. The order of strokes here needs special attention
column11: both because it falls outside the general principles we have learned already
column12: and because it involves writing the element for bound up in an order opposite to the one we learned. If it is any consolation
column13: this exception is consistent every time these three strokes come together."		3	I bound ten thousand dollars together and hid it under the floor. column13: eight "To the right we see a head and to the left an element that means craft. When we think of a paragraph

column1: 94 "" separate 別 べつ different; separate separate
column7: the samurai and his saber were never separated. They were constant companions
column8:
like the cowboy of the Old West and his six-shooter. This character depicts what must have been the height of separation-anxiety for a samurai: to be bound up with a rope and unable to get at his saber leaning only a few feet away from him. Look at that mouth bellowing out for shame and sorrow! Note the order in which the element for tied up is written - just as it had been with the character for ten thousand. 7 I don´t know about you but to me this seems like someone´s head is about to be separated from his body. You can see he´s kneeling and his mouth is wide open gasping for the last breath he will ever take. A wise old samurai keeps his hostages (with their mouths bound up to keep them quiet) in a separate room from his sabers. Putting them together would be a silly mistake. 別 べつに【別に】(not) particularly; nothing / separately; apart

column7: ground "That´s right - a ri. Don´t bother looking it up in your English dictionary; it´s a Japanese word for measuring distances. One ri is about 4 kilometers or 2.5 miles. The kanji depicts how the measure came to be used. Atop we see the rice field
column8: and below the element for land. Those four sections you see in the rice field (and which we made mention of when first we introduced the character in frame 14) are actually measurements of land
column9: much the same as farm-sections in the United States have given us the notion of a ""country mile."" The land division based on the size of a rice field is called a ri." "* To get a more concrete primitive meaning for this kanji

column4: but I can assure you they are used only when absolutely necessary. One rin is equal to about 1/1000 of a yen - or rather was worth that much when it still made economic sense to mint them. While inflation took its toll on this kanji as a monetary unit

column1: 195 "" yonder 向く むく to face yonder
column6: mouth "Something referred to as ""over yonder"" is usually far off in the distance and barely within sight - like a wee drop in the distance - and is usually an expression used in giving directions or pointing something out. Hence this kanji begins with a drop. Then we find a sort of transparent helmet with no eyes or nose
column7: but only a prominent mouth under it
column8: obviously an extraterrestrial. And what is it jabbering on about with its mouth open like that? Why

column1: 197 "" character 字 じ character (i.e. kanji) character
column3: child Here is the character for character itself. Not just kanji
column4: but any written character from hieroglyphs to Sanskrit to our own Roman alphabet. It shows us simply a child in a house. But let us take advantage of the double-meaning of the key word to note that just as a child born to a Japanese house is given characters for its name

so it is also stamped with the character of those who raise it from infancy on. 6 CHILDren learn Kanji characters underneath a HOUSE. "Why do I have to wear this roof on my head all the time father? ""Shut up! It builds character!""." 字 "もじ; もんじ【文字】letter (of alphabet); character / literal

column10: one "Under the primitive for house we meet the kanji for span. Think of the key word in its religious sense of missionary preaching: ""proclaiming the good news to all nations"" and ""shouting it from the housetops."" That should be enough to help you remember this simple kanji
column11:
used in fact both for traditional missionary work as well as for one of its contemporary replacements: advertising." 9 You can proclaim your opinions from the comfort of your HOUSE and have it SPAN the entire globe these days via The Internet. column1: 226 "" calendar 暦 こよみ calendar; almanac calendar
column8: tree2
column9: wood2	Look at this character in reverse order
column10: from bottom up. First we see the primitive for days
column11: an appropriate enough way to begin a calendar. Next we see a grove of trees growing under a cliff. The laws of nature being what they are
column12: the trees would be stunted under such conditions
column13: unless they were strong enough to keep growing upwards until they passed through the layers of rock and soil
column14: right up to the surface. Now imagine that in those little boxes marking off the days on your wall calendar
column15: you see that very process taking place step by step: 365 or so time-lapse pictures of that grove of trees each month
column16: from January under the cliff to December on top of the cliff. The story is not as complex as it sounds
column17: particularly if you happen to have a calendar nearby and can flip through it with this image in mind. 14 Years-Months-Days: It takes many years for a cliff to form or erode. A tree takes many months to grow. But days pass by regularly - so in this way
column18: we see the movement of time such as with a CALENDAR.	This is just a picture of a wall calendar with a page for each month. The bottom half has the grid of days
column19:
the top half has a pretty picture of a forest this month. The cliff radical here is the top and left edges of the paper. You can see the paper curling up at the lower left where a breeze is trying to turn the page. 暦 こよみ; れき【暦】calendar; almanac
